I can't enjoy playing this game and, thus, cannot recommend it for three reasons:

I have a dedicated button bound for yaw left/right and pitch up/down because it is impossible to turn as quickly using mouse movement. Having spent roughly 20+ hours playing the game via it's standalone launcher (at time of writing, 01/11/2015) and now migrating to STEAM, I have found this to be an impressive early access game. I have found it easy to pick up and play, highly enjoyable and generally a worthwhile investment of time. I've not sunk this much energy into a game for a considerable period.

Points of concern for people coming into the game, who may be new to early access, could be; The limited selection of levels and weapons. There is a reasonable amount for the stage of development that the game is in but people should be aware that it is early in the state of development and thus still hasn't got a full feature set.

There have been some issues with controls, particularly mouse. At time of writing, I can happily attest that my mouse is working and extremely comfortable, though the issue persists for others. Descendent Studios has been hugely active within the community in it's attempts to resolve this issue.

The game, though easy to pick up, can be unforgiving if you're new to it. Likewise if you are unsued to six degrees of freedom movement (6dof) or the fact that ships have specific physics to their turn rate/movement.

As a note; for those who have an interest in feedback/information on the development of the game, generally the amount of information and developer involvement with the community is quite high. I've yet to experience a situation where I've not felt like I know what is going on.

I can happily recommend this game. It's an awful lot of good fun. It is likely not for everyone but anyone who has a love of arena-style Quake or UT games may wish to give it a look.

Over fifteen years ago, I fell in love with the unique mix of exploration and threats-from-anywhere combat provided by the Descent 1 and 2 single player campaigns. Then, I discovered Kali and the chaotic twisting madness of Descent multiplayer. Around 2005, my new computer could no longer run Descent, and, after searching in vain for a game that offered the same thrill of maneuvering just at the edge of your control, I concluded that the modern games industry no longer cared about players like me.

Descendent Studios has proven that conclusion premature.

Descent: Underground has all the core components for thrilling multiplayer combat already in place. The drones handle excellently and have real tradeoffs in maneuverability, speed, size, power, and special tools. More importantly, the devs are pushing beyond the multiplayer of the originals by incorporating supporting roles to encourage team-based play.

For example, in Proving Grounds, I've been playing the Shaman, which has a healing ability, during team anarchy games. That healing capability naturally pushes me to navigate the map with teammates and spontaneously cooperate in taking down opponents, turning team anarchy from anarchy where you shouldn't shoot some people" into a real team game. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Writing a review of a Steam Early Access game can often be challenging. You are asked to judge a title that is still on the developer’s desk, something that is constantly changing and evolving. Things you like or don’t like will probably get changed before the title releases, and what you are playing is usually missing some big components that won’t get put in there until right before the game goes gold.

So, how do you evaluate and review an Early Access game, especially one with big shoes to fill?  After playing Descent Underground for an extended period of time, it becomes clear that the best approach is to look at the core elements of the game, its soul, and even the emotions it evokes when you play.  Putting aside things like missing pieces that are still being developed or balanced, or any of those modern buzz words that we use to describe technical hurdles yet to overcome, playing Descent Underground can only be described as pure enjoyment.

All of the pieces of a truly wonderful game are already there, and incredibly polished even at this early phase. As a person who grew up playing Descent in high school, my expectations were extremely high, and my praise hard to come by for any new title with the franchise name attached. Descent has a certain cachet that no one else has been able to replicate. That rush to a fierce firefight with guns lit up, those claustrophobic and tight tunnel runs in the dark, the incredibly nuanced and deeply personal duels in multiplayer. It was a rare bird, the total package of anarchy covered in cool. After just a few minutes back in the saddle, with my flight stick in my hand, it is clear all of the magic is back, and Descent Underground flies, and fights, exactly how it should. Descent is back.

Sure, there are more new visual elements than there are old.  There are several different ships, now styled as drones to fly, and a few new gadgets in there too.  The maps are modern works of geometric art, and the visuals are commensurate with a high-end modern game.  But the bones of Descent, the freedom, the rush, the feeling of graceful flight, fierce battles, and a tight game that overwhelms your senses again and again is right there. The stuff that matters most. You feel connected, hooked up, part of the game, where your controller merges you with a precision machine, and how you fight and fly is an extension of you.

So that is where Descent Underground succeeds, and why it will always succeed as it goes through the rest of its development and eventual release out into the world. It has soul. No matter what else gets bolted on, the foundation is gold, Rock of Gibraltar solid, and every inch of it is thoughtful, faithful, and above all, FUN.

Early Access Review

This development team delivered big time.  The game is FUN! When I get home from work, this is the game I want to play.   They produced a fun working game in 4 months.   For the next 8 months, they're going to be adding a ton of stuff to it.

This game is what early access is all about.  Early access is often code for an incomplete game that will never be complete.   Not here.   This team keeps pumping out new content, keeping it fresh and exciting AND they've already delivered content months in advance of schedule. When is the last time you've heard of a game coming out early?

TWO big thumbs up for this game.

Now for an actual review of the game:

Right now it is multiplayer only.  The single player is down the line, so I am only reviewing what is here today.  The multi-player is intense.  The game is basically a 3d version of Quake.  After playing this game, other First person shooters will seem overly simplistic and annoying that you are stuck to a 2 dimenstional ground.  In this game, you can evade in any direction.

Warning:  The game is skill based.  When you first start playing, expect to get worked.  But then you'll learn the dos and don'ts of 6 degrees of freedom dog figthing and before you know it, you'll be able to earn an even kill to death ratio (that's where I'm at right now), but THEN you'll wind up in a game w/ really good players and you'll realize you have a lot more to learn.  Which I think is a good thing.

The more you play, the more addicted it gets, because you realize there are strategies that will help you earn more kills.  One of the saving graces is your ship comes with two laser grids that you can drop behind you in narrow tunnels.  This basically kills anyone who runs into it.  So it's a great escape mechanism that helps noobies like me avoid getting hunted down.  As you start getting more advanced, you'll realize you want to power up your lasers before you get into combat so pick up and upgrade your weapons as soon as you spawn.  It takes a LONG time to kill someone with level one weapons.  Second, the vulcan cannon looks like machine gun bullets, and it is effective at a distance, since the bullets travel fast and there is a tight spread.  In contrast, the lasers do more damage, but are slow.  Lasers are great up close.

I am excited to see how team game play gets fleshed out.  Right now, the predominant game type is anarchy, which is basically everyone for themselves.  If you're looking for a great deathmatch game in space, this is the game to get.

Later on, a team component will be added and a single player campaign.

Early Access Review

I dunno. I will recommend based on that it is quite true to its spiritual predecessor, Descent, but...

So far in early access what we see is a bare-bones menus UI, a bunch of differently purposed ships (classes), 5 different multiplayer maps (which I expect and hope are demo maps rather than part of the final product), unfinished effects, not particularly interesting enemies, and really quite poor AI (particularly considering the quality and variation of AI in the original games all those years back).

What is finished does look quite good. The controls plays like they should: movement is good, targetting could maybe be a bit more challenging (though fighting in full 3D can be challenging enough for many people). The ships and environments look good (textures, meshes). In-game UI looks similar to Descent, and still does it's job (I don't think radar works yet). The environments are diverse and interesting, AI is a little challenging in numbers (but no AI tactics like in Descent 3). Sounds are interesting. Atmosphere is pretty much spot-on.

So, I think the game is probably coming along as planned or close to, even though we are approaching the published release date (March 2016) with the early access being barely a demo.

Then I think, I really like the look of NeonZSX. Indie game. Very descent like (obvious inspirations). And it's a sandbox game. And it's indie. And it looks large. And it looks like it has lots to do. And it has randomised worlds. And it's got very good reviews.
http://store.steampowered.com/app/296010/?snr=1_620_4__45

So, I can't recommend this game without also recommending taking a look at NeonZSX. This is more true to the original. NeonZSX looks like it takes it to the next step. I don't think either will be like Descent 4, but I'll probably give them both a go, myself.

Review, Impressions, Hopes?

6dof achieved!!! and classic descent flight is done very well. However...

Wheres the levels? I get its early access but the few maps that it comes with are SUPER tiny. They also are quite horizontal. the first 2 Descent games had maps that would give u vertigo - they were endless mazes that had you forgetting where the exit was and madly scrambling and backtracking as the reactor counts down to zero.

I sincerely hope the pickup holograms are temporary. The bright floating holographic colours clashes with the beautiful level detail and it reminds me of mario coins or some childrens game from the early 2000's. The weapon pickups that would float in D1 & D2 were high quality at the time, and made dying and retrieving your weapons an absolute joy. Now they are all 2d images inside diamonds that often block vision through cramped corridors. I would love to see a quality weapon model either floating classicaly or as a sort of scannable item through the hud from a destroyed drone or old tech left behind. (However the latter would be deviating from classic Descent - but i think it would satisfy as a next gen method to getting upgrades)

Enemy briefing before each level was also something that made Descent special. As you got stronger so did the regiments of drones that were added. Seeing a model with a description and specs made finding it and encountering it in combat something to look forward to - or be fearful of. I hope this is not left out in the single player release.

I am not bashing these guys for the current state of this game, i realize its under development and that there are budget constraints. I just hope the end goal is to modernize this franchise and bring back some of the charm that made it a game far ahead of its time!

This is a perfect game for the Oculus Rift (tested on DK2) and shows immense potential for its upcoming single player campaign.

The developers warn about possible VR discomfort so in my first run - a simple test flight - I went at the controls as aggressively as I possiblyt could, and failed to create any discomfort whatsoever; no short of trying very, very hard. The end result is I kind of got very familar with the maps, twisting and twirling through them like I stole the drone I'm operating.

Having finally given a shot at multiplayer, I can safely say that this is the most fun I've had in a multiplayer combat environment in a long time. The VR helps with situational awareness, and if you've got the heart to pull the moves and control aggressively, you'll feel like a Jedi. (Even when you get blown to smithereens)

As for people playing on monitors, I can't help but think this delivers. The key element of this game - the one that rushes me to a positive rating - are the controls, which for the first time I can say truly reincarnate what I remember of the original Descent series, which I played a lot in the 90's. Many have tried to bring back the magic since, and haven't quite pulled it off. This one feels like Descent is finally back.

Looking forward to the single player campaign as well. I can imagine boss fights could be brutally enjoyable, especially in VR. Some performance improvements are definitely needed but all in all this has, for me, delivered.

For the single player, as I imagine most of you are: Wait

For the multi-player fanatic with like-minded friends:  Maybe.  If you are interested in actively giving constructive feed-back to the devs then actually sure, but if that's you then you are likely the minority and I can't in good conscious give a positive review based on appeal to a rather unique subset of the gaming population.

Still hoping that just maybe one of these old-school reboots knocks it out of the park, this one definately shows potential.

Ive played all the older descents, and used to play D3 a lot on multiplayer. In its current state I wouldnt recommend the game for old descent multiplayers the following reasons.

Maps are pretty claustrophobic. There are two maps that are playable in multiplayer, as they offer at least some space for maneuvering. The maps are also quite small in overall size, which is good in the current state of the playerbase. Usually I find a handful of players to play with at best, but I do play during the day in Europe so that could also be part of the problem.

The afterburner has been pretty much made useless. In its current state it is used as a consumable, and the game is pretty slow in tempo because you cant really use the boost as you would in the older versions.

The game is graphically okay, though the ships do seem quite outdated. What bothers me more about the ships is that they move kind of twitchy. This is probably due to servers in being in the US and Im playing from Europe. Some of the ships jump around a lot, and the multiplayer is barely enjoyable.

Gonna end on a positive note. The graphics are nice overall, and the ships handle pretty well. Weapons are the old favourites. I hope the dev team does focus on the multiplayer, as that will keep the playerbase alive. Overall the game feems familiar, though the ships feel kinda tame(afterburner).
